unnormalised: What time is it in India right now compared to the US? It's kinda confusing.
normalised: What time is it in India right now compared to the U-S? It's kind of confusing.

unnormalised: Well, it depends on *which* part of the US you're talking about! India follows Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. That means it's 5 hours and 30 minutes ahead of Greenwich Mean Time. The US, on the other hand, has several time zones: Eastern Time (ET), Central Time (CT), Mountain Time (MT), and Pacific Time (PT). And don't forget about Alaska and Hawaii!
normalised: Well, it depends on *which* part of the U-S you're talking about! India follows Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five hours and thirty minutes. That means it's five hours and thirty minutes ahead of Greenwich Mean Time. The U-S, on the other hand, has several time zones: Eastern Time (E-T), Central Time (C-T), Mountain Time (M-T), and Pacific Time (P-T). And don't forget about Alaska and Hawaii!

unnormalised: For instance, if it's 2 PM IST in Delhi, it would be 4:30 AM ET in New York, 3:30 AM CT in Chicago, 2:30 AM MT in Denver, and 1:30 AM PT in Los Angeles. Keep in mind that Daylight Saving Time (DST) might affect these calculations during certain months. DST usually begins in March and ends in November in most parts of the US, adding an hour to the time difference. So, to be absolutely sure, you can always google "time in [specific US city]" vs. "time in India". You can also use websites like worldtimebuddy.com which are very helpful.
normalised: For instance, if it's two P-M I-S-T in Delhi, it would be four thirty A-M E-T in New York, three thirty A-M C-T in Chicago, two thirty A-M M-T in Denver, and one thirty A-M P-T in Los Angeles. Keep in mind that Daylight Saving Time (D-S-T) might affect these calculations during certain months. D-S-T usually begins in March and ends in November in most parts of the U-S, adding an hour to the time difference. So, to be absolutely sure, you can always google "time in [specific U-S city]" versus "time in India". You can also use websites like worldtimebuddy.com which are very helpful.

unnormalised: So, a quick tip: ET is usually 9 hrs 30 mins behind India during standard time and 8 hrs 30 mins behind during DST. Always double-check esp. around March 10th and Nov 3rd each year to see if DST is in effect! Hope this helps!
normalised: So, a quick tip: E-T is usually nine hours thirty minutes behind India during standard time and eight hours thirty minutes behind during D-S-T. Always double-check especially around March tenth and November third each year to see if D-S-T is in effect! Hope this helps!
